Title: Prove that $SL(2,\mathbb{R})$ acts transitively on the upper half plane
Content: I want to prove $\mathrm{SL}(2,\mathbb{R})$ acts transitively on the upper half plane $\mathbb{U}:=\{z\in \Bbb C\ |\ \mathrm{Im}(z)>0\}$ by $$z\longmapsto \dfrac{az+b}{cz+d}.$$ Is it enough to say that since $\begin{pmatrix} a & b\\c & d \end{pmatrix}\in \text{SL}(2,\mathbb{R})$ is always invertible, for $x,y\in \mathbb{U}$ , we can always find a matrix $A\in \text{SL}(2,\mathbb{R})$ such that $Ax =y$ ? I feel like there should be more to it.
AcceptedAnswer: Suppose $\;z\in\Bbb C\,,\;w\in\Bbb H\;$, and write $\;w=n+im\;,\;\;n,m\in\Bbb R\;,\;m>0\;$: $$\frac{az+b}{cz+d}=w\iff (a-cw)z=dw-b\iff z=-\frac{dw-b}{cw-a}$$ and $$-\frac{dw-b}{cw-a}\cdot\frac{c\overline w-a}{c\overline w-a}=-\frac{cd|w|^2-adw-bc\overline w+ab}{|cw-a|^2}=$$ $$=-\frac{ab+cd|w|^2+(ad+bc)n}{|cw-a|^2}+\frac{\overbrace{(ad-bc)}^{=1}m}{|cw-a|^2}i$$ so also $\;z\in\Bbb H\;$ and we're done

$\mathbb{U}$ is the upper half-plane $\{ z \in \mathbb{C} \mid \mathrm{Im}(z) > 0 \}$.

Prove that the action of $\mathrm{SL}(2,\mathbb{R})$ on $\mathbb{U}$ is transitive (i.e., for any $x, y \in \mathbb{U}$, there exists $A \in \mathrm{SL}(2,\mathbb{R})$ such that $A.x = y$).
